name: Kepler-444
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-444 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-444 is a star with 0.76 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.75 times its radius. It is located 118.98 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 11.23 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-444 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-444 system


Kepler-444 b

Kepler-444 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The radius of Kepler-444 b is 0.403 that of Earth.


Kepler-444 c

Kepler-444 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The radius of Kepler-444 c is 0.497 that of Earth.


Kepler-444 d

Kepler-444 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The radius of Kepler-444 d is 0.53 that of Earth.


Kepler-444 e

Kepler-444 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The radius of Kepler-444 e is 0.546 that of Earth.


Kepler-444 f

Kepler-444 f was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The radius of Kepler-444 f is 0.741 that of Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-444, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
